questions.text: Which of the following is a false rib?
questions.solution:
The 8th rib is the false rib because it does not articulate with the sternum anteriorly.

  • First 7 ribs are true ribs as they are attached anteriorly to the sternum by costal cartilages.
  • Ribs 8-10 are false ribs as they join the superjacent costal cartilage.
  • Ribs 11 and 12 are floating ribs as they float freely without costal attachment.

Related Pearl: Articulations of ribs

 Joints
  • Costovertebral: Rib to the vertebral body  
  • Costotransverse: Rib to the transverse process of vertebra
  • Costochondral: Rib to the costal cartilage

Articulations with the vertebrae

Ribs 2 to 9: 3 articulations

  • Head of the rib to the inferior costal facet of the vertebral body above
  • Head of the rib to the superior costal facet of the corresponding vertebral body
  • Tubercle of the rib to the transverse process of the corresponding vertebra

Rib 1: 2 articulations

  • Head of the rib to the corresponding vertebral body
  • Tubercle of the rib to the transverse process of the corresponding vertebra

Ribs 10, 11 and 12: 1 articulation

  • 10th rib - upper border of the tenth thoracic vertebra near its pedicle
  • 11th, 12th ribs - Head of the rib to the corresponding vertebral body

Articulations with the sternum

Ribs 1- 7: True ribs - Articulate directly with a single costal cartilages 

Ribs 8 - 10: False ribs - Articulate with a common costal cartilage.

Ribs 11 and 12: Floating ribs - Do not articulate with the sternum

questions.text: Which of the following joints is not formed by direct articulation with ribs?
questions.solution:
The costosternal joint is not formed by direct articulation with ribs. The costosternal joint is formed by the articulation of the lateral sternal border with the costal cartilages of the ribs.

Related Pearl: Articulations of ribs

 Joints
  • Costovertebral: Rib to the vertebral body  
  • Costotransverse: Rib to the transverse process of vertebra
  • Costochondral: Rib to the costal cartilage

Articulations with the vertebrae

Ribs 2 to 9: 3 articulations

  • Head of the rib to the superior costal facet of the corresponding vertebral body
  • Tubercle of the rib to the transverse process of the corresponding vertebra

Rib 1: 2 articulations

  • Head of the rib to the corresponding vertebral body
  • Tubercle of the rib to the transverse process of the corresponding vertebra

Ribs 10, 11 and 12: 1 articulation

  • 10th rib - upper border of the tenth thoracic vertebra near its pedicle
  • 11th, 12th ribs - Head of the rib to the corresponding vertebral body

Articulations with the sternum

Ribs 1- 7: True ribs - Articulate directly with a single costal cartilages 

Ribs 8 - 10: False ribs - Articulate with a common costal cartilage.

Ribs 11 and 12: Floating ribs - Do not articulate with the sternum

questions.text: What type of joint is the first sternocostal joint?
questions.solution:
The first sternocostal joint is a type of synarthrosis.

Joints are classified in 2 ways:

Classification 1 is based on the type of motion (functional):
  1. Synarthrosis - no movement (first sternocostal joint)
  2. Amphiarthrosis - some movement (pubic symphysis)
  3. Diarthrosis - full movement (elbow/shoulder/ankle)
Classification 2 is based on the structure of joint:
1. Fibrous
  • Sutures (joints between skull bones)
  • Syndesmoses (distal tibiofibular joint)
  • Gomphose (joint between teeth and teeth sockets in mandibular/maxillary bone)

2. Cartilaginous

  • Synchondrosis - primary cartilaginous (costochondral joints)
  • Symphysis - secondary cartilaginous (manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints)

3. Synovial (elbow, knee, hip etc.)

  • the presence of these help the thoracic cavity expand during inspiration. E.g.:
    • Interchondral joint
    • Sternocostal joint
    • Costovertebral joint
    • Costotransverse joint

questions.text: The joint between the attachment of the 8th and 9th rib to the 7th rib is a:
questions.solution:
The interchondral joint between the attachment of the 8th and 9th rib with the 7th rib is a synovial joint.

Joints in the thoracic cavity are of the following types:

  • Synarthrosis - structures are connected by a fibrous band of tissue. E.g, 1st sternocostal joint
  • Synchondrosis - primary cartilaginous joints. E.g., costochondral joints
  • Symphysis - secondary cartilaginous joints. E.g. manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints 
  • Synovial joints - the presence of these help the thoracic cavity expand during inspiration. E.g.:
    • Interchondral joint
    • Sternocostal joint
    • Costovertebral joint
    • Costotransverse joint

Note: 

The interchondral joint between the 9th and 10th cartilages is never synovial and sometimes absent.

questions.text: Which of the following does not provide articulations to ribs?
questions.solution:
The spinous processes of vertebrae do not provide articulation to ribs.

Note: 

Two facets on head of the ribs are separated by a transverse crest which is attached to the intervertebral disc above it. 

Related Pearl: Articulations of ribs

 Joints
  • Costovertebral: Rib to the vertebral body  
  • Costotransverse: Rib to the transverse process of vertebra
  • Costochondral: Rib to the costal cartilage

questions.text: Which of the following ribs is atypical and doesn't articulate with the vertebra at 3 sites?
questions.solution:
1st rib is an atypical rib and does not articulate at 3 sites with a vertebra. It has 2 articulations as follows:

  • Circular facet on the head of the rib with the body of the first thoracic vertebra
  • Tubercle of the rib to the transverse process of the corresponding vertebra

Ribs are divided based on anatomical features as typical and atypical.

Typical ribs:

Ribs 3 to 9 are typical. A typical rib is curved, and has a shaft with anterior and posterior ends:

  • The anterior end has costal cartilage
  • The posterior end has a head, neck, and a tubercle and articulates with the vertebra at 3 sites as follows:
    • The head has 2 facets and articulates with the vertebra at 2 sites
    • The tubercle has articular and nonarticular surfaces. The articular surface articulates with the transverse process

Atypical ribs:

Ribs 1, 2, 10, 11, and 12 are atypical. 

  • 1st rib - it is flat. The head has only a single articular facet. The superior surface has a scalene tubercle. 
  • 2nd rib - the external surface of the shaft has a rough area, where the serratus anterior attaches.
  • 10th rib - the head has a single facet.
  • 11th and 12th ribs - the head has 1 large facet. They don't have necks or tubercles.

Related Pearl: Articulations of ribs

 Joints
  • Costovertebral: Rib to the vertebral body  
  • Costotransverse: Rib to the transverse process of vertebra
  • Costochondral: Rib to the costal cartilage

Articulations with the vertebrae

Ribs 11 and 12: Floating ribs - Do not articulate with the sternum

questions.text: A 47-year-old smoker presented with cough, chest pain, dyspnea, and right shoulder pain. Chest X-ray revealed homogeneous opacity at the lung apex and destruction of the first rib. Which of the following is not compressed?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario and chest X-ray features are suggestive of a tumor at the apex of the right lung, also called Pancoast tumor. The thoracic duct does not lie between the 1st rib and the apex of the lung, so it will not be compressed. The thoracic duct crosses from right to left in the mediastinum at the level of T5 and ascends upwards to drain into the venous system. 

The structures present between the 1st rib and apex of the lung (medial to lateral) can be remembered using the mnemonic SVAN:

  • Sympathetic trunk
  • Vein - Posterior intercostal
  • Artery - Superior intercostal
  • Nerve - T1 nerve

Clinical significance:

Pancoast tumors can cause destruction of the first rib by mass effect. Given below is an X-ray image of a Pancoast tumor (marked as P).

questions.text: Which of the following structures passes through the marked area in the diagram below?
questions.solution:
The marked area is the groove anterior to the scalene tubercle on the first rib. The subclavian vein passes through this.

It is structures passing through the grooves around the scalene tubercle are:

  • Anterior groove - Subclavian vein.
  • Posterior groove - Subclavian artery and lower trunk of brachial plexus.

The image below shows the relations of the first rib

questions.text: The image given below shows structures in the posterior triangle of the neck. Where does the structure marked A attach?
questions.solution:
The structure marked A is the scalenus anterior. It attaches on the first rib on its scalene tubercle. 

The scalene tubercle is a small projection on the medial (inner) border of the 1st rib, between two grooves.

Structures passing through these grooves are

  • Anterior groove - Subclavian vein.
  • Posterior groove - Subclavian artery and lower trunk of brachial plexus.

Option B: The tuberculum sellae is a part of the sphenoid bone and is present within the sella turcica

Option D: The Chassaignac tubercle or carotid tubercle is present on the transverse process of C6. The carotid pulsations are palpated by pressing against this.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles seen below does not attach to the first rib?
questions.solution:
In the given image, the scalenus posterior marked as C has no attachment on the first rib. It attaches to the second rib.

Other structures marked are:

A - Scalenus anterior

B - Subclavius

D - Scalenus medius

The attachments on the 1st rib are:

  • Subclavius
  • Scalenus anterior
  • Scalenus medius
  • First digitation of serratus anterior
  • Suprapleural membrane
  • Costoclavicular ligament

questions.text: The relationship of the components of the neurovascular bundle from below upwards in intercostal space is _______
questions.solution:
The arrangement of the components of the neurovascular bundle in the intercostal space from below upwards is nerve-artery-vein. 

The arrangement can be remembered from above downwards with the mnemonic VAN: vein-artery-nerve.

questions.text: In the costal groove of which of the following ribs is the classic arrangement of vein-artery-nerve is not seen?
questions.solution:
The classic vein-artery-nerve arrangement is not seen in the 1st rib.

In the first rib, the arrangement of structures seen medial to lateral are as follows: SVAN

  • Sympathetic trunk
  • Vein (intercostal)
  • Artery (superior intercostal)
  • Nerve (T1 nerve)

questions.text: What does the tip of the T3 spinous process correspond to?

choices.text: Root of the spine of scapula

questions.solution:
The tip of the T3 spinous process corresponds to the root of the spine of the scapula

Other important surface markings of scapula:

  • Superior angle of scapula: at the level of 2nd rib and vertebra T2.
  • Inferior angle of scapula: opposite the T7 vertebral spinous process.

Related Pearl: Spinous Processes and their Significance

Spinous process

Significance

C2 spinous process

Most superior bony protuberance in the midline inferior to the skull

C7 spinous process

Lower extent of ligamentum nuchae

T3 spinous process

Level of the root of the spine of the scapula

T7 spinous process

Level of the inferior angle of the scapula

T12 spinous process

Midpoint of a vertical line between the inferior angle of the scapula and the iliac crest

L4 spinous process

Level marks the highest point of the iliac crest

S2 spinous process

Sacral dimples that mark the position of the posterior superior iliac spine are level

In thoracic vertebrae, the tips of thoracic spinous processes lie at the level of the vertebral body below.

E.g., T3 spinous process lies at the level of T4 vertebral body

In lumbar and sacral regions, the tips of spinous processes reflect the position of their corresponding vertebral bodies

E.g., L 4 spinous process lies at approximately the L4 vertebral level

questions.text: Which among the following is incorrect regarding Sibsons’s fascia?

choices.text: Attached to the inner border of 2nd rib

questions.solution:
Sibson’s fascia is attached to the inner border of the 1st rib, not the 2nd rib.

Sibson's fascia (suprapleural membrane) serves as a plane of separation between the lower neck and the thorax and covers the apical part of the lung. It is attached to the inner border of the 1st rib and posteriorly to the anterior border of the transverse process of the C7 vertebra. It is strengthened by a few spreading muscular fibers derived from the scalene muscles. The subclavian vessels lie on top of it.

questions.text: On the ides of March, Julius Caesar was stabbed 23 times. One such stab wound was present in the left supraclavicular fossa, piercing his left lung. Which of the following provides the vertebral attachment to the fascia present here?
questions.solution:
The stab injury penetrated the apex of the lung. It is covered by Sibson's fascia, also known as the suprapleural membrane. Attachment of Sibson's fascia is at vertebra C7.

Sibson's fascia is attached:

  • Anteriorly to the inner border of the first rib
  • Posteriorly to the anterior border of the transverse process of the C7 vertebra.
